text: Cross-linking of <extra_id_0> CD44 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on rheumatoid synovial cells up-regulates <extra_id_0> VCAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
<extra_id_0> CD44 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a ubiquitous molecule also known as hyaluronic acid or homing receptor .
However , the cellular functions and its role in inflammation , for example , rheumatoid synovitis , are currently unknown .
In this study , we propose a novel function for <extra_id_0> CD44 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Using synovial cells from rheumatoid arthritis ( RA ) patients , we demonstrated that <extra_id_0> CD44 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cross-linking and binding to hyaluronan augmented <extra_id_0> VCAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression and subsequently <extra_id_0> VCAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated cell adhesion .

text: These results indicate that the adhesion of RA synovial cells to matrices such as hyaluronic acid through <extra_id_0> CD44 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> could up-regulate <extra_id_0> VCAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression and <extra_id_0> VCAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated adhesion to T cells , which might in turn cause activation of T cells and synovial cells in RA synovitis .

text: We therefore propose that such cross-talking among distinct adhesion molecules may be involved in the pathogenesis of inflammation , including RA synovitis .
